row = 4 square 1 can be substituted for household items of a similar diameter a 15mm needle will draw up a loop with a circumference of ~47mm or ~24mm tall 2 can be substituted for household items of a similar diameter a 20mm needle will draw up a loop with a circumference of ~63 mm or ~31mm tall stitches and abbreviations american terminology is used chain = chain st = stitch single_crochet = single_crochet fsc = foundation single_crochet stsc = stacked single_crochet half_double_crochet = half_double_crochet bl = work in back loop only r = row fp = forward pass rp = return pass special stitches forward passes are worked from left to right for right-handed crocheters and right to left for left-handed crocheters return passes are worked the opposite r to l for rh l to r for lh any broomstick lace stitch can be swapped for another in the pattern as long as you ve cast on the right number of loops to meet the multiple so you can freely eliminate any stitch that you don t care for tbl = traditional broomstick lace requires loops in multiples of 5 20mm knitting needle suggested 1 fp pull up loops through the bl and add them to your knitting needle for more stability you can lock your loops by doing a blch and then adding your working loop to your knitting needle 2 rp bring 5 loops off your knitting needle on to your hook single_crochet 5 through all 5 loops repeat until you work through all loops sbl = straight broomstick lace no required multiple 15mm knitting needle suggested 1 fp pull up loops through the bl and add them to your knitting needle for more stability you can lock your loops by doing a blch and then adding your working loop to your knitting needle 2 rp bring 1 loop off your knitting needle on to your hook single_crochet 1 through the loop repeat until
